qa_pairs.question: What were the fates of the Home Bank of Canada and the Bank of Vancouver, and which sources describe these?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Home Bank of Canada incorporated in 1903, opened in 1904, and failed in 1923.<cite>[S217][S218][S219]</cite></statement> <statement>The Bank of Vancouver was organized in 1908, opened in 1910, and failed in 1914.<cite>[S155][S156][S157]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: What is the significance of the Desjardins Group in the Canadian credit union sector, and how does its asset size compare to the combined assets of credit unions outside Quebec as of 2022?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Desjardins Group is significant in the Canadian credit union sector as it operates as a network that includes most credit unions in Quebec and some outside the province, fostering collaboration and shared resources among its members.<cite>[S121]</cite></statement> <statement>As of 2022, the combined assets of credit unions outside Quebec totaled $308.9 billion, while the Desjardins Group reported consolidated assets of $407 billion as of December 2023, indicating its substantially larger asset base compared to non-Quebec credit unions.<cite>[S120][S123]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S114] Canada has a strong co-operative financial services sector, which consists of credit unions (caisses populaires in Quebec and other French speaking regions). [S115] At the end of 2001, Canada's credit union sector consisted of 681 credit unions and 914 *caisses populaires*, with more than 3,600 locations and 4,100 automated teller machines. [S116] By the end of 2019, consolidation reduced this number to 251 credits unions and caisses populaires outside Quebec, according to the Canadian Credit Union Association (CCUA). [S117] Canada has the world's highest per capita membership in the credit union movement, with over 10 million members, or about one-third of the Canadian population. [S118] While the sector is active in all parts of the country, it is strongest in the western provinces and in Quebec. [S119] In Quebec 70 per cent of the population belongs to a caisse populaire, while in Saskatchewan close to 60 per cent belongs to a credit union. [S120] ### Credit unions outside Quebec

As of 31 December 2022, the 208 credit unions and caisses populaires outside Quebec reported combined assets of $308.9 billion:

### Desjardins

Most credit unions in Quebec (and some outside the province) are part of a network which operates as the Desjardins Group. [S121] Desjardins Group owns and operates a range of subsidiaries, including a securities brokerage, a venture capital firm, and a bank based in Florida. [S122] As of 25 December 2023, Desjardins Group's consolidated assets totalled $407 billion CAD. [S123] | Name | Institution No | Total assets (2023) (CAD) (Billions) | Employees (FTE) | Source |

[S114] Canada has a strong co-operative financial services sector, which consists of credit unions (caisses populaires in Quebec and other French speaking regions). [S115] At the end of 2001, Canada's credit union sector consisted of 681 credit unions and 914 *caisses populaires*, with more than 3,600 locations and 4,100 automated teller machines. [S116] By the end of 2019, consolidation reduced this number to 251 credits unions and caisses populaires outside Quebec, according to the Canadian Credit Union Association (CCUA). [S117] Canada has the world's highest per capita membership in the credit union movement, with over 10 million members, or about one-third of the Canadian population. [S118] While the sector is active in all parts of the country, it is strongest in the western provinces and in Quebec. [S119] In Quebec 70 per cent of the population belongs to a caisse populaire, while in Saskatchewan close to 60 per cent belongs to a credit union. [S120] ### Credit unions outside Quebec

qa_pairs.question: How does the acquisition of HSBC's Canadian division by RBC affect the concentration of banking assets in Canada, and what is the significance of this in relation to the D-SIB designation?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The acquisition of HSBC's Canadian division by RBC increased the share of banking assets held by Canada’s Big Six from 93% to almost 95%, further concentrating banking assets in the country. <cite>[S12]</cite></statement><statement>Canada’s Big Six, including RBC, are designated as Domestic Systemically Important Banks (D-SIBs) due to their critical role in the economy. Their concentration amplifies the systemic risk posed by their failure, as their collapse could disrupt financial services and harm the economy. <cite>[S13][S14][S15][S16]</cite></statement>

[S1] List of banks and credit unions in Canada


# List of banks and credit unions in Canada



This is a **list of banks in Canada**, including chartered banks, credit unions, trusts, and other financial services companies that offer banking services and may be popularly referred to as "banks". [S2] ## Largest banks


### Big Five

The top five Canadian banks are collectively referred to as the "Big Five" due to their dominant position and significant influence within the country's banking and financial industry. [S3] This term has been used for many years to characterize these major banks, and it highlights their substantial market share and impact on Canada's economy. [S4] The financial sector of Canada is especially concentrated in these banks, which has been seen as a result of protectionist policies of the government and the country's small and dispersed population. [S5] These banks grew at an extraordinary rate of 10.7 percent per year, on average, from 2008 to 2018 compared with 3.64 percent for the five largest U.S. [S6] banks. [S7] While most Canadian banks operate only within Canada, the Big Five are best described as Canadian multinational financial conglomerates that each have a large Canadian banking division. | Royal Bank of Canada | RBC | 003 | $187.21 | $53.66 | $14.86 | 95,000+ |
| Toronto-Dominion Bank | TD | 004 | $154.21 | $49.20 | $10.78 | 103,257 |

### Big Six

National Bank of Canada, which began as a regional bank in Quebec but expanded nationally, is the sixth largest Canadian bank. [S9] In 2022, Canada’s Big Six held about 93% of all banking assets in the country. [S10] It is the same share they held a decade earlier, and a decade before that. [S11] RBC’s $13.5-billion takeover of HSBC’s Canadian division, announced in November 2022, will see it receive around $134 billion in HSBC assets and would increase the 93% share of assets the Big Six have to almost 95%. ## Importance of Canada's financial institutions


### Domestic systemically important bank (D-SIB)

A domestic systemically important bank (D-SIB) is a bank that could disrupt the domestic economy should it fail. [S13] Canada's Big Six are designated as D-SIBs. [S14] D-SIBs are so important to the functioning of the financial system and the economy that they cannot be wound up under a conventional bankruptcy and liquidation process should they fail. [S15] The failure of any one of Canada’s D-SIBs, with the potential loss of financial services, even for a short period of time, could have a serious impact on Canada’s economy. [S16] ### Desjardins

The Autorité des marchés financiers, which oversees Quebec’s financial sector, designated Desjardins Group as a D-SIB.

qa_pairs.question: What distinguishes Schedule I banks from other types of banks in Canada, and how many of these are credit unions as of 8 March 2024?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Schedule I banks in Canada are distinguished by being domestic banks that are not subsidiaries of foreign banks, even if they have foreign shareholders.<cite>[S24]</cite></statement> <statement>As of 8 March 2024, there are 35 domestic banks classified as Schedule I, including 3 federally regulated credit unions.<cite>[S25]</cite></statement>

[S17] ### Global systemically important bank (G-SIB)

A global systemically important bank is a bank whose systemic risk profile is deemed to be of such importance that the bank’s failure would trigger a wider financial crisis and threaten the global economy. [S18] The Basel Committee has developed a formula for determining which banks are G-SIBs, deploying criteria including size, interconnectedness and complexity. [S19] National regulators subject banks determined to be G-SIBs to stricter prudential regulation such as higher capital requirements and extra surcharges, or more stringent stress tests. [S20] In Canada, the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions designated Royal Bank of Canada and Toronto-Dominion Bank as G-SIBs as well as D-SIBs. [S21] ## Banks by legal classification

Banks in Canada are classified by their ownership as domestic banks, subsidiaries of foreign banks, or branches of foreign banks. [S22] For a greater explanation of the classifications, see *Banking in Canada* and *Bank Act (Canada)*. [S23] ### Schedule I banks (domestic banks)

qa_pairs.question: What is the difference in credit union membership rates between Quebec and Saskatchewan, and how does this compare to the national average mentioned in the context?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The difference in credit union membership rates between Quebec and Saskatchewan is 10 percentage points, with Quebec at 70% and Saskatchewan at 60%.<cite>[S119]</cite></statement> <statement>The national average membership rate for credit unions in Canada is approximately 33.3%, as over 10 million members represent about one-third of the Canadian population.<cite>[S117]</cite></statement> <statement>Both Quebec and Saskatchewan have significantly higher credit union membership rates than the national average, with Quebec's rate being more than double the national average and Saskatchewan's rate nearly double.<cite>[S117][S119]</cite></statement>

[S114] Canada has a strong co-operative financial services sector, which consists of credit unions (caisses populaires in Quebec and other French speaking regions). [S115] At the end of 2001, Canada's credit union sector consisted of 681 credit unions and 914 *caisses populaires*, with more than 3,600 locations and 4,100 automated teller machines. [S116] By the end of 2019, consolidation reduced this number to 251 credits unions and caisses populaires outside Quebec, according to the Canadian Credit Union Association (CCUA). [S117] Canada has the world's highest per capita membership in the credit union movement, with over 10 million members, or about one-third of the Canadian population. [S118] While the sector is active in all parts of the country, it is strongest in the western provinces and in Quebec. [S119] In Quebec 70 per cent of the population belongs to a caisse populaire, while in Saskatchewan close to 60 per cent belongs to a credit union. [S120] ### Credit unions outside Quebec

### Desjardins

Most credit unions in Quebec (and some outside the province) are part of a network which operates as the Desjardins Group. [S121] Desjardins Group owns and operates a range of subsidiaries, including a securities brokerage, a venture capital firm, and a bank based in Florida. Okay, let's tackle this question. The user is asking about the difference in credit union membership rates between Quebec and Saskatchewan, and how that compares to the national average mentioned in the context. 

First, I need to look through the supporting context provided. The passage has two parts, but the relevant info is probably in Passage 1. Let me scan through the sentences.

Looking at the sentences, [S119] says, "In Quebec 70 per cent of the population belongs to a caisse populaire, while in Saskatchewan close to 60 per cent belongs to a credit union." That gives the specific numbers for Quebec and Saskatchewan. So Quebec is 70%, Saskatchewan is 60%. The difference between them is 10 percentage points.

Next, the national average. In [S117], it states, "Canada has the world's highest per capita membership in the credit union movement, with over 10 million members, or about one-third of the Canadian population." So the national average is about 33.3% (one-third). 

Now, comparing Quebec's 70% and Saskatchewan's 60% to the national average of 33.3%. Both provinces have higher membership rates than the national average. The question asks for the difference between Quebec and Saskatchewan, which is 70% - 60% = 10%, and how they compare to the national average. 

I need to make sure there are no other mentions of national average elsewhere. Scanning through other sentences, [S118] mentions the sector is strongest in western provinces and Quebec, but doesn't give another average. So [S117] is the key for the national average.

So the answer should state that Quebec has 70%, Saskatchewan 60%, difference of 10%, and both are higher than the national average of ~33.3%. The citations would be [S119] for the provincial numbers and [S117] for the national average.

[S1] List of banks and credit unions in Canada


# List of banks and credit unions in Canada



This is a **list of banks in Canada**, including chartered banks, credit unions, trusts, and other financial services companies that offer banking services and may be popularly referred to as "banks". [S2] ## Largest banks


### Big Five

The top five Canadian banks are collectively referred to as the "Big Five" due to their dominant position and significant influence within the country's banking and financial industry. [S3] This term has been used for many years to characterize these major banks, and it highlights their substantial market share and impact on Canada's economy. [S4] The financial sector of Canada is especially concentrated in these banks, which has been seen as a result of protectionist policies of the government and the country's small and dispersed population. [S5] These banks grew at an extraordinary rate of 10.7 percent per year, on average, from 2008 to 2018 compared with 3.64 percent for the five largest U.S. [S6] banks. [S7] While most Canadian banks operate only within Canada, the Big Five are best described as Canadian multinational financial conglomerates that each have a large Canadian banking division. ### Big Six

National Bank of Canada, which began as a regional bank in Quebec but expanded nationally, is the sixth largest Canadian bank. [S9] In 2022, Canada’s Big Six held about 93% of all banking assets in the country. [S10] It is the same share they held a decade earlier, and a decade before that. [S11] RBC’s $13.5-billion takeover of HSBC’s Canadian division, announced in November 2022, will see it receive around $134 billion in HSBC assets and would increase the 93% share of assets the Big Six have to almost 95%. ## Importance of Canada's financial institutions


### Domestic systemically important bank (D-SIB)

A domestic systemically important bank (D-SIB) is a bank that could disrupt the domestic economy should it fail. [S13] Canada's Big Six are designated as D-SIBs. [S14] D-SIBs are so important to the functioning of the financial system and the economy that they cannot be wound up under a conventional bankruptcy and liquidation process should they fail. [S15] The failure of any one of Canada’s D-SIBs, with the potential loss of financial services, even for a short period of time, could have a serious impact on Canada’s economy. [S16] ### Desjardins

The Autorité des marchés financiers, which oversees Quebec’s financial sector, designated Desjardins Group as a D-SIB.

[S17] ### Global systemically important bank (G-SIB)

A global systemically important bank is a bank whose systemic risk profile is deemed to be of such importance that the bank’s failure would trigger a wider financial crisis and threaten the global economy. [S18] The Basel Committee has developed a formula for determining which banks are G-SIBs, deploying criteria including size, interconnectedness and complexity. [S19] National regulators subject banks determined to be G-SIBs to stricter prudential regulation such as higher capital requirements and extra surcharges, or more stringent stress tests. [S20] In Canada, the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions designated Royal Bank of Canada and Toronto-Dominion Bank as G-SIBs as well as D-SIBs. [S21] ## Banks by legal classification

Banks in Canada are classified by their ownership as domestic banks, subsidiaries of foreign banks, or branches of foreign banks. [S22] For a greater explanation of the classifications, see *Banking in Canada* and *Bank Act (Canada)*. [S23] ### Schedule I banks (domestic banks)

## Credit unions

[S114] Canada has a strong co-operative financial services sector, which consists of credit unions (caisses populaires in Quebec and other French speaking regions). [S115] At the end of 2001, Canada's credit union sector consisted of 681 credit unions and 914 *caisses populaires*, with more than 3,600 locations and 4,100 automated teller machines. [S116] By the end of 2019, consolidation reduced this number to 251 credits unions and caisses populaires outside Quebec, according to the Canadian Credit Union Association (CCUA). [S117] Canada has the world's highest per capita membership in the credit union movement, with over 10 million members, or about one-third of the Canadian population. [S118] While the sector is active in all parts of the country, it is strongest in the western provinces and in Quebec. [S119] In Quebec 70 per cent of the population belongs to a caisse populaire, while in Saskatchewan close to 60 per cent belongs to a credit union. [S120] ### Credit unions outside Quebec
